title: Am I rejecting God if I don’t listen to Christian music? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is “God” or “god”, really? Well, in a metaphysical sense, it might be possible that there is one “God”. But that is not the reality here on Earth. On Earth, there are many “gods”, proclaimed by PEOPLE (not a God or Gods) who make a lot of noise that their “god” is THE “God”. ABSOLUTE COMPLETE FUCKING BULLSHIT. The real situation is that everyone on Earth has their OPINION of what their god is, and then takes that same OPINION and tries to sell you it as being “THE GOD”. That does not change the fact that this is their OPINION. An opinion is not a fact. When you die, if there is such a god or God, then you might be in a position to discern what really is fact. Until then, everything on this Earth, except perhaps mathematics and a few other exceptions - everything else is one person’s opinion. There are 330 million people in the United States. As a result, there are 330 different version of “god” too. Just like you will never please all 330 million people, you will never please all of their respective “gods” either. Everyone wants to be “God”. Everyone thinks that they are “God” and good. The fact is, no one is “God”, regardless of what they think, and no one can prove with factual empirical evidence that is recognized by accredited professionals that such a “God” even exists - and the defense to this statement is usually a politically-charged comeback. If your “god” feels that your are reject him or her, because you are not following petty rules and jumping through hoops, then that is simply what you believe. Maybe you are right, but I doubt it. If I was “God”, I think I would be much more concerned about what people actually did, than their taste in music. If I was “God”, I would not be so lacking in self-confidence that I needed to be serenade by pious zealots to give me validation. Those emotional problems are symptomatic of those who create those own “gods” and superimposed them on an unknown metaphysical deity, and not such a deity itself. Here is the reflective problem: If A = 1, then 1 = A, right? Therefore, if “God” “allegedly” made man in his own image, then the opposite is true: MAN MAKES HIS VERSION OF GOD IN HIS OWN IMAGE. Each person’s god and belief system is merely a reflection of their own psychological makeup, cultural world view, insecurities, values, ideas and beliefs - but has nothing to do with a metaphysical deity that no one can prove even exists, yet make wild claims that they have a direct communication channel to (and only if you send $19.95 and get the Jim Bakker audio tapes…). I have gotten pulled into many religion conversations, despite every effort to change the subject and keep my mouth shut, because for some reason, Mark D. Gerardy’s personal “salvation” is of paramount importance to them, or so they can confuse their politics as somehow being charitable work. Short List of Some Religious Psychological Traps: Collective GuiltCircular ReasoningFearGroup-ThinkBuilding a logical house of cards on assumptionsHearsaySpeculationSpeculating on the Intent of othersPoliticsCulture WarsProjecting own’s own insecurities onto the feelings and motives of an alleged dietyThe Style PoliceLabeling everything that does not fit one’s extremist bias as “New Age”Labeling the reasonable middle-ground as “bias and radical”What feels goodDefensive Posturing: “Regardless of what I have done, if you hurt my feelings in any why when calling me out, then I am absolved of all sin and then YOU are the one who is morally-wrong: because you hurt my feelings” (that are impossible not to hurt by calling someone out in the first place).I rattled off that list in less than two minutes. There are a lot of very intelligent people in this world, some of which have their act-together, and some of which still do dumb things. And there are a lot of indoctrinated people, some are “Christians”, and many have used their faith in the name of many good things - hospitals, universities, research - and some have also used their faith in the name of lynching and firebombing. The same is true with the Muslim faith, there is much good in the same spirit as the Christian faith, and then there are folks who fly airplanes into building in the name of their so-called “God”. I do not believe in worshiping unreasonable or cruel gods or “God”. If this so-called spiritual path is going to be fraught with listening to this music, having this style of clothing, believing these tenets, treating this group this way and that group that way…then honestly, I would be seriously-questioning the validity of such a religion. What really matters? If I was a hippie and cut off all my hair, then would you care? Should you care? Would a “God” really care? Now if I flew a jumbo jet into a skyscraper, then would you care? Should you care? Would a “God” really care? I am not going to live my life tiptoeing on the narrowest of tightropes to placate a fertility cult full of power-hungry bullying hypocrites that call themselves a church, such so they can get their jollies off about adding another spiritual-zombie and political foot-soldier to their flock to dominate and control, because they attempted to scare the Hell out of me and I was a fool enough to believe their propaganda. If any such deity expected me to perform spiritual-gymnastics and live in fear my entire life of “never being good enough”, then I would reject such an evil and cruel god. It is not difficult to discern what is good and what is not. While many churches are indeed good and can and do many good things for a lot of folks, nonetheless, there are a large number of folks who do not require remedial training in ethics. I cannot say the same regarding a number of parishioners and churches themselves, and they know that too.

Er no. I'm a Christian albeit not a very good one and I don't listen to Christian music. Christian music encompasses a huge number of genres from hip hop to heavy metal. And although there's one or two which are good and even in some instances broken into mainstream, its not my cup of tea. Theres certainly no commandment to listen to Christian music in the Bible. Although we are advised to be careful in everything. 1 Corinthians 6 v 12 Everything is permissible for me"--but not everything is beneficial. "Everything is permissible for me"--but I will not be mastered by anything. So no you aren't rejecting God by not listening to Christian music. In fact that could be taken the the nth degree…you reject God if you don't shop at a Christian grocery store, don't buy soap made by a Christian soap maker, watch ChristIan TV, shine shoes for black people (the latter has been suggested by a so-called Christian who runs a Fried Chicken chain of restaurants-FORTUNATLY there none of his white-hating crap outlets here in the UK! ) and don't buy your fried chicken from our friend. If you want to listen to Christian music then fine. If you don't then that's also OK. Chick-fil-A CEO urges white people to 'shine a black stranger's shoes'

The point of the church, and everithing it does is to spread the joyous word (prostylaterisation) by converting nonbelievers, and to guide the christian communities with the accordance with his word (the bible). Christians tend to employ various tactics to preach and convert non-believers, or to encourage people to live a sinless life, among them, music, due to it’s widespread popularity as a source of entertainment. Music is mostly used for the latter purpose (encouragment to lead a moral life) because people who listen to christian music are usually…christians. Music can be a good way of doing this, but can also be misguided, as people who write the music are often not the people who can correctly interpret the bible (I’m speaking from a catholic standpoint, but this is also true if the messeges in the song don’t correlate with your own denomination) . It is not required to listen to christian music to lead a virtous life, as even a virtous pagan can enter heaven if he leads a moral life, the only problem is that for that pagan it is difficult to lead that life as no one ever thought him how to lead it, whitch is the purpose of the priests. I’m sorry for the grammar errors, english is not my first language. I hope you can understand my anwser.

No but you are rejecting good music by listening to Christian music. I’m joking obviously, but don’t be fooled by Christian music. A lot of Christian artists are insincere or mixed at best, they preach and sing on stage and get drunk and seduce really innocent girls backstage. Christianity is a schtick for them. A way to make money and get noticed when they wouldn’t have in secular music. There are many reports of Christian artists not being what they claim to be. Mainstream music has many Christians and they’re honest about not being perfect and try a lot harder to live better lives. I’m sure that there are many Christian artists that practice what they preach and that’s ok. Just be wary of anyone who claims to have all the answers. I think real Christians understand that they don’t always understand or know what God wants of them and they’re going through a spiritual journey like everyone else.

No, a relationship with God consist of way more than what music or clothes or whatever some people are worried about or deem as “evil” or unkind in the eyes of God. How would they know? Are they there by his side? If you live a life that you feel is right and do everything you can to show that you put in the effort and belief that his way is what you want to go. Nobody is perfect, and nobody has a better picture in his eyes because of the fact that we are all making mistakes, and that`s not the point, the point is that if you do make a mistake and realise it and put some effort into correcting it. The intentions and actions will define what your relationship with God and whethter or not you`re rejecting him and his offered helping hand. We were given a great number of abilities from free thinking to making choices, the ability to construct systems, to create art if these abilities were inherently evil, why would we have them? It is how you use and understand them. Hopefully this mess is helpful.

No! ““Christian Music” is just another way of saying a gener of music like Classical or Rock and Roll. God created many different types of music for everyone. This is to go along with our free will. Music is very much enjoyed by emotion and or taste. Hymns were originally meant for entertainment and to speak a message. The same goes for some religious chants sung sermons. Therefore God’s Message is in the music as well as his grace. Before the ““Born Again Christians” start arguing about this, I don’t want to see it or hear from any of you. You have your opinion of Christianity I have mine. The Two will never mix.

No. Listening to Christian music doesn’t make you a Christian any more than going to church makes you a Christian. There are many that do everything that a Christian is supposed to do, but in their hearts they still reject God. Listening to Christian music is a good thing since it helps to focus your attention on God and the majority contains good biblical meaning in the lyrics. It is also not loaded with vulgarities and things that are contrary to Gods desires… But no, not listening to it does not mean you reject God. Though, if you are opposed to Christian music, it may be a symptom of you withdrawing from God.

In short, no. Some “Christian” music is dreadful, and a whole lot more is mediocre at best. What makes music - or any art - “Christian” anyway? If a Christian carpenter makes a table, is it a Christian table? Is any pot a Christian makes a Christian pot? If we believe the Bible, God is everywhere and He gives us all gifts. Everyone, not just believers. It’s called common grace. We’re all made in the image of the Creator, so we are all creative, regardless of creed. If you see God’s wonder in a song, great. If God speaks to you in a Tarantino movie, brilliant. We can’t make God so small that He only inhabits what Christians make. He’s there, but not just there. But who knows, maybe I’m a heathen with no Bethel on my Spotify.

No, you’re not “rejecting” god. Christian scripture says “Make a joyful noise unto the lord”…it doesn’t say anything about what kind of joyful noise to make. The important part seems to be the word “joyful”. You were created to respond to beauty and joy in all things…nature, family and friends, art, learning, love, and music. So no matter what kind of music gives you joy, it’s no sin, no betrayal and no rejection to listen to it, move to it, create it, sing it, love it and shout it out…the louder the better. It’s a gift, and you don’t throw a gift back in the giver’s face.

Well you could include it in your music collection. There are many awesome songs and they don’t have too all be Christian to enjoy them. Life isn’t so black and white. That is just plain religious and God is not so rigid that he doesn’t allow musicians to know him regardless of their style or talent. We bring glory to God by realizing his ultimate sacrifice was to give us his son Jesus to reveal his true love for us. Praise songs are pleasing to the Lord and uplifting spiritually speaking, but music and the different styles and songs out there can just be a form of relaxation and enjoyment. Music helps me out through the day and I admire many different styles and songs.

First of all, “rejecting God” is doing things accordingly “against” his will and choosing to refuse to believe and acknowledge his existence. On the other hand, listening to music or doing any other form of entertainment is not rejecting God per se.. but it can affect your stand against God (assuming you're a Christian) depending on what kind of music or what form of entertainment you chose. With that said, just bear in mind that music with negative influence will also have negative impact on your spirituality.

No. God is not a Christian. What is Christian? Was Jesus a Christian? No. God is love. Get quiet and listen to your heart. Keep the seven virtues and have faith. Adam had no Christian music and neither did Jesus. Follow what Jesus said and you’ll find the answers. Seek and you shall find. Test all things. Be grateful and loving in all moments and you will see all the blessings God has for you. Be like Children, joyful, easy to forgive and forget.

Since God was around before radio or revision broadcasting, or choirs of any kind, I think someone is trying to guilt trip you into following their taste in music. Tell them to grow up and realize that the morning stars were singing together long before any Christian band! And that is still heard in the chorus of Creation at dawn and does not require a single human voice to produce it.

No. God is not a Christian. And god did not create Christian music. I am not a christian, but I was raised one in a family with a long lineage of Christian pastors. But what I have learned in my life is that a personal relationship with God does not have to be through a religion. God speaks to all of us from the inside.

NO, you are rejecting crappy Christian music and that is all. You are given the right to make choices that work for you. To be a Christian, according to Jesus, all you have to do is accept him as your Savior. That’s it. The rest is bullshit that Christianity tries to use to control you.

No. Listening to Christian music doesn't make you any more Christian than another Christian who listens to Christian music. It is all how you choose to worship Jesus and how you want your relationship with Jesus to be.

Your life is made up many things listening to Certain music is not a standard but to some people it seems to be..You have to say besides religious music there is more than just music to make up your beliefs and preferences…Pray, read a bible or ask a minister mainly remember that God and music is one of many ways but it is certainly not the only one…

Not in the slightest. Most Christian music is crap. Just slapping the label “Christian” on anything doesn’t make it good (or Christian). I do like the singer Chris Amerson. Lovely voice, but its not Rock or pop.

No, but try it. There is a lot of Christian music that is very modern and have a lot of rythmn. Along with uplifting words that encourage and help you through rough spots in your life. I know it helped me so much through several rough spots in life. Just listen once in awhile for an hour or so, see if you might learn to enjoy it.
No, just because you dont listen to christian music doesn't mean you don't believe in God any1 saying otherwise are wrong your beliefs are yours

Good music is about as close to the divine as we can get in a material world. It doesn’t matter where that music comes from, it speaks to the soul. Having said that, I have found that a lot of Christian Rock rejects the sublime in exchange for pandering.
Not all Christian music is feeling towards god to share ( Maybe ) U could make your music , new music as closer to god.
no as long as you dont let it affect you in a bad way u live in the world but dont be apart of the world may God bless everyone that reads this and your family and friends
Hell no! I have just discovered a great satirist, Roy Zimmerman. Listen to his music on youtube. Here’s my current favourite.
No your not, if fact Jesus never sang songs, nor did he sing during his sermons, so dont let ppl scare you into thinking that
NO god lies in us not in music.
You listen to Christian music to fill your home and your spirt with the love of God and to let the Holy Ghost manifest inside you . To uplift your spirit and soul .
No. Your soul has a song.
Yes, and it is a sin.
No.
no
No
No
